definition: The conditions that a product, service, or result must satisfy to be accepted by the stakeholder or customer.
example: The software must load within 2 seconds and support 10,000 concurrent users.

definition: A change request that has been reviewed and authorized for implementation.
example: The project manager approved a change request to add new features after stakeholder feedback.

definition: Conditions or facts that are accepted as true in the absence of proof.
example: We assume that all team members will have access to the required software licenses.

definition: A fixed reference point that represents the approved version of a deliverable or plan.
example: The project baseline includes the scope, schedule, and budget approved by stakeholders.

definition: A set of procedures and systems to document, approve, and implement changes to the project.
example: The change control system requires all changes to be submitted in writing and approved by the CCB.

definition: The process of identifying, documenting, and controlling versions of project components.
example: Configuration management ensures that all software versions are tracked and compatible.

definition: Limitations or restrictions that affect the project's execution or results.
example: The project has a budget constraint of $500,000 and a time constraint of 12 months.

definition: An action taken to address a performance deviation and bring the project back into compliance.
example: A corrective action was implemented to reduce the schedule variance by reassigning resources.

definition: A product, service, or result that must be produced to complete a project or process.
example: The first deliverable is a detailed project plan due at the end of month one.

definition: An action taken to reduce the probability of a negative project event.
example: Preventive actions included staff training to reduce the risk of quality defects.

definition: A document that formally authorizes the project and gives the project manager authority to allocate resources.
example: The project charter was signed by the sponsor and distributed to all stakeholders.

definition: The series of phases that a project passes through from initiation to closure.
example: The project lifecycle included planning, execution, monitoring, and closure phases.

definition: The document that describes how the project will be executed, monitored, and controlled.
example: The project management plan includes scope, schedule, budget, quality, and risk management plans.

definition: The approved version of the project's scope, schedule, and cost baselines.
example: The performance baseline was used to measure project progress and identify variances.

definition: A document that describes the products, services, or results to be delivered by the project.
example: The SOW specified that the software must include user authentication and data encryption.

definition: A condition or capability that must be met or possessed by a product, service, or result.
example: A key requirement is that the system must be accessible to users with disabilities.

definition: The sum of all products, services, and results to be provided by a project.
example: The project scope includes building a mobile app with five core features.

definition: The approved project scope statement and all approved and authorized change requests.
example: The scope baseline serves as the reference for controlling scope changes.

definition: The unauthorized expansion of the project scope beyond what was originally approved.
example: Scope creep occurred when the client requested additional features without formal change approval.

definition: The document that describes how project scope will be defined, validated, and controlled.
example: The scope management plan outlined the process for reviewing and approving scope changes.

definition: A narrative description of the project's products, services, and results.
example: The scope statement defined what the project would and would not include.

definition: An individual, group, or organization that has an interest in or may be affected by the project.
example: Key stakeholders include the project sponsor, team members, and end users.

definition: A hierarchical decomposition of the project scope into smaller, manageable components.
example: The WBS divided the project into phases, then into deliverables, then into work packages.

definition: A specific task or work that must be performed as part of the project.
example: Building the database schema is an activity with a duration of 5 days.

definition: The estimated amount of time required to complete an activity.
example: The activity duration for testing was estimated at 2 weeks.

definition: The process of identifying dependencies and sequencing project activities.
example: Activity sequencing determined that testing must occur after development.

definition: The process of calculating the late finish and late start dates for project activities.
example: The backward pass determined when each task must start to finish on time.

definition: The longest sequence of dependent activities that determines the project's completion date.
example: The critical path included design, development, and deployment with zero slack.

definition: A schedule network analysis technique to identify the critical path and calculate float.
example: CPM analysis revealed that shortening design by 2 days would reduce the project timeline.

definition: A relationship between two activities where one is dependent on the completion of the other.
example: There is a finish-to-start dependency between design and development.

definition: The earliest date when an activity can be completed.
example: The early finish for the design phase was calculated to be March 15.

definition: The earliest date when an activity can begin.
example: The early start for development was set to April 1 after design completion.

definition: The amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the project end date.
example: The testing activity had 3 days of float and could be delayed without impacting the deadline.

definition: The process of calculating the early start and early finish dates for activities.
example: The forward pass determined the earliest possible start and finish for each task.

definition: A bar chart that displays project activities on a timeline showing their duration and sequence.
example: The Gantt chart visually showed all activities, dependencies, and the critical path.

definition: The latest date when an activity can be completed without delaying the project.
example: The late finish for the design phase was May 10 to maintain the project schedule.

definition: The latest date when an activity can begin without delaying the project.
example: The late start for development was April 15, after which the project would be delayed.

definition: A delay between two dependent activities.
example: A 2-day lag was added between the end of development and the start of testing.

definition: An advance on a successor activity that can occur before the predecessor is complete.
example: Testing could start 1 day before development finished due to a lead relationship.

definition: A significant point or event in the project schedule with zero duration.
example: Project kickoff and the completion of design are key milestones.

definition: A graphical representation of the project schedule showing activities and dependencies.
example: The network diagram showed how each activity depended on others.

definition: A statistical technique that uses optimistic, pessimistic, and most likely estimates.
example: PERT estimated the design duration as 15 days (optimistic: 10, pessimistic: 20, likely: 15).

definition: A technique to resolve resource conflicts by adjusting the schedule.
example: Resource leveling delayed non-critical activities to avoid overallocating the senior developer.

definition: The approved schedule for the project, used to measure performance.
example: The schedule baseline showed the project would be completed on June 30.

definition: A technique to reduce the schedule duration without reducing project scope.
example: Schedule compression was achieved by crashing critical path activities and adding resources.

definition: The document that describes how the project schedule will be managed.
example: The schedule management plan specified that all schedule changes require sponsor approval.

definition: The difference between earned value and planned value, indicating schedule performance.
example: A negative schedule variance of -$10,000 indicated the project was behind schedule.

definition: An estimation technique using optimistic, pessimistic, and most likely scenarios.
example: The three-point estimate for testing was 8 days (optimistic), 12 days (likely), and 18 days (pessimistic).

definition: The total amount of money approved to execute the project.
example: The project budget is $500,000 spread across 12 months.

definition: The approved budget for the project, used as the basis for cost control.
example: The budget baseline included all planned costs with a contingency reserve.

definition: The sum of approved budgets for scheduled project work.
example: The cost baseline was used to measure earned value and cost performance.

definition: A ratio of earned value to actual cost indicating cost efficiency.
example: A CPI of 1.2 means the project is spending $0.83 for every dollar of work completed.

definition: The difference between earned value and actual cost, showing cost performance.
example: A positive cost variance of $5,000 indicated the project was under budget.

definition: The value of work actually completed at a given point in time.
example: If 50% of the project is complete, the earned value is 50% of the total budget.

definition: The projected total cost of the project at completion.
example: The EAC indicated the project would cost $550,000 due to current cost performance.

definition: The estimated cost to complete remaining project work.
example: The ETC was calculated as $50,000 based on current burn rate.

definition: The document that describes how project costs will be estimated, budgeted, and controlled.
example: The cost management plan specified that all expenses over $5,000 require approval.

definition: The document that describes how the organization will implement its quality policy.
example: The quality management plan defined quality standards and inspection procedures.

definition: The process of auditing and monitoring project activities to ensure quality standards.
example: Quality assurance reviews identified process improvements to prevent defects.

definition: The process of monitoring specific project results to verify they meet quality standards.
example: Quality control testing ensured that each software module met acceptance criteria.

definition: An imperfection or lack of conformance to specifications in a deliverable.
example: A critical defect was discovered in the authentication module and fixed immediately.

definition: Action taken to correct a defect or bring a nonconforming product into compliance.
example: Rework was required on 15% of components due to defects found during inspection.

definition: Incremental or breakthrough changes to enhance project processes.
example: Process improvement initiatives reduced defect rates by 40%.

definition: A technique to examine a portion of items within a population to make conclusions.
example: Statistical sampling was used to inspect 10% of products for quality assurance.

definition: The difference between planned and actual results in cost, schedule, or scope.
example: A schedule variance of 2 weeks indicated the project was behind its baseline.

definition: The document that describes how project resources will be acquired and managed.
example: The resource management plan identified staffing needs and acquisition strategies.

definition: The process of assigning project resources to activities and work packages.
example: Resource allocation assigned the senior developer to critical path activities.

definition: A technique to balance resource usage and demand across the project.
example: Resource leveling adjusted the schedule to avoid overloading any single team member.

definition: The group of individuals performing project work under the direction of the PM.
example: The project team consisted of developers, QA engineers, and business analysts.

definition: A graphical representation of resource usage over time.
example: The resource histogram showed peak staffing needs in months 3 and 4.

definition: The document describing how and when human resources will be acquired.
example: The staffing plan indicated that senior developers would be needed starting month 2.

definition: The document that describes communication methods, frequency, and responsible parties.
example: The communications plan specified weekly status meetings with stakeholders.

definition: A document that communicates project progress against the baseline.
example: The weekly status report included schedule, budget, and risk updates.

definition: A meeting that officially starts the project and aligns all parties on objectives.
example: The kick-off meeting introduced the team and reviewed the project charter.

definition: The process of providing information to stakeholders in a timely manner.
example: Regular stakeholder communication ensured alignment and buy-in throughout the project.

definition: The document that describes how project risks will be identified and managed.
example: The risk management plan outlined the process for identifying, analyzing, and responding to risks.

definition: An uncertain event or condition that could affect project objectives.
example: Key risks included resource unavailability and technology changes.

definition: A document that records identified risks and their characteristics.
example: The risk register included 25 identified risks with probability and impact ratings.

definition: A tool to assess and prioritize risks based on probability and impact.
example: The matrix classified risks as high, medium, or low based on their probability and impact.

definition: The strategies and actions to address identified risks.
example: The risk response plan included mitigation, avoidance, and contingency strategies.

definition: A risk response strategy to reduce the probability or impact of a risk.
example: Risk mitigation included redundant servers to reduce downtime probability.

definition: A predetermined action plan for responding to a risk event.
example: The contingency plan outlined steps to take if the lead developer became unavailable.

definition: Time or cost buffer allocated for identified risks.
example: A 10% contingency reserve was included in the budget for identified risks.

definition: Time or cost reserved for unknown risks and management decisions.
example: A 5% management reserve was set aside for unforeseen circumstances.

definition: The document that describes how project procurements will be managed.
example: The procurement plan identified vendor selection criteria and contract types.

definition: The process of acquiring goods or services from external sources.
example: Procurement of software licenses required competitive bidding.

definition: The process of evaluating and selecting suppliers or vendors.
example: Vendor selection was based on cost, quality, and delivery timeframes.

definition: A document soliciting proposals from potential vendors.
example: The RFP detailed requirements and requested pricing from three vendors.

definition: A formal document ordering goods or services from a vendor.
example: The purchase order specified quantity, price, and delivery date.

definition: A legally binding agreement between the buyer and seller.
example: The contract outlined deliverables, payment terms, and penalty clauses.

definition: The process of managing stakeholder engagement to satisfy their needs and resolve issues.
example: Stakeholder management included regular meetings with key sponsors.

definition: The process of identifying and analyzing stakeholder characteristics and interests.
example: Stakeholder analysis revealed that users had concerns about data privacy.

definition: A strategy for engaging stakeholders at appropriate times and levels.
example: The engagement plan specified communication frequency with different stakeholder groups.

definition: A tool to classify stakeholders by their power and interest in the project.
example: The power/interest grid helped identify which stakeholders needed close management.

definition: A technique to measure project performance using cost and schedule indicators.
example: EVM analysis showed the project was 10% over budget but on schedule.

definition: A document tracking issues, owners, and resolution dates.
example: The issue log contained 8 open issues with priorities and assigned owners.

definition: A formal request to modify project scope, schedule, budget, or quality.
example: A change request was submitted to add new features to the software.

definition: A committee that reviews and approves or rejects change requests.
example: The CCB met weekly to review proposed changes and their impacts.

definition: The process of finalizing all project activities and transferring deliverables.
example: Project closure included final documentation and knowledge transfer to the client.

definition: Knowledge gained during the project that can improve future initiatives.
example: Lessons learned included the importance of early stakeholder communication.

definition: Meeting project objectives within scope, schedule, budget, and quality constraints.
example: Project success was achieved when all deliverables were completed on time and within budget.

definition: The person or organization who provides resources and authorizes the project.
example: The project sponsor approved the budget and provided executive support.

definition: The person responsible for planning, executing, and controlling the project.
example: The project manager coordinated all activities and reported progress to the sponsor.

definition: In agile, the facilitator who removes impediments and supports the team.
example: The scrum master helped the team resolve daily impediments.

definition: In agile, the person responsible for managing the product backlog.
example: The product owner prioritized features based on customer feedback.

definition: An iterative project management approach emphasizing flexibility and customer feedback.
example: The agile approach allowed the team to respond quickly to changing requirements.

definition: In agile, a fixed time period (usually 2-4 weeks) for completing work.
example: Each sprint included planning, execution, and review meetings.

definition: In agile, a prioritized list of work items and features.
example: The product backlog contained 150 features prioritized by business value.

definition: In agile, a meeting where the team reflects on what went well and what can improve.
example: The retrospective identified that better communication would improve velocity.

definition: In agile, a brief daily meeting where team members share progress and impediments.
example: The daily standup ensured the team stayed aligned on priorities.

definition: In agile, a simple description of a feature from a user's perspective.
example: A user story read: 'As a user, I want to reset my password so I can regain access.'

definition: In agile, the criteria that work must meet to be considered complete.
example: Definition of done included testing, code review, and documentation.

definition: In agile, the amount of work a team can complete in a sprint.
example: The team's velocity was 40 story points per sprint.
